<div class="post-text" itemprop="text">
<p>I have a 32x32 matrix of float numbers. I want to get a sum of all the elements in it. But when I use loop:</p>
<pre><code>s = 0
for i in range(len(Temp)):
    for j in range(len(Temp)):
        s += Temp[i][j]
</code></pre>
<p>I get <strong>2.795541576006144e-13</strong></p>
<p>And when I use NumPy <code>.sum(..)</code> method:</p>
<pre><code>np.sum(Temp)
</code></pre>
<p>I get <strong>3.197442310920451e-13</strong></p>
<p>The results are pretty different, so which is right?</p>
<p>P.S. can't show the array I use for an example above, because it says my post is mostly code</p>
<pre><code>[  1.46992605  -4.38174259   7.11556386  -9.63811941  11.89561903

  -5.51985755   1.90225724]

</div>
<div class="post-text" itemprop="text">
<p>They are both correct. Please see that it is such small number that in both cases it is almost zero (because of e-13 part).</p>
<p>Please see this post about floating point arithmetic issues and limitations: <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/floatingpoint.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/floatingpoint.html</a></p>
</div>
<span class="comment-copy">Can you please show sample data for the 30x30 matrix</span>
<span class="comment-copy">I tried, but it says my post is mostly code</span>
<span class="comment-copy">Then can you please post in in a comment to me</span>
<span class="comment-copy">in the comments it says "too long by 13798 characters"</span>
<span class="comment-copy">Then can you please post part of it</span>
<span class="comment-copy">While this is true, the relative difference (about 10%) is still astonishing. Still, since none of the numbers have more than 8 decimal digits, a result o.t.o.o. <code>e-13</code> means "zero with some rounding errors".</span>
